content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.

entries.title: Best text-to-speech software of 2025
entries.snippet:
This document from TechRadar (dated September 29, 2025) presents a comprehensive guide to the best text-to-speech (TTS) software of 2025. It emphasizes the growing importance of TTS for accessibility, productivity, and content creation, particularly in media like YouTube and podcasting.

The top picks include:

1. **NaturalReader** – Best overall for personal/home use, offering 56 voices across 9 languages and cloud-based access.
2. **Murf** – Best for realistic AI voices, ideal for e-learning and presentations, with advanced editing and voice-changing tools.
3. **Amazon Polly** – Best for developers, offering easy API integration and broad language support.
4. **Play.ht** – Best for podcasting, providing nearly 600 voices in over 60 languages, with options tailored for commercial use.
5. **Voice Dream Reader** – Best for Mac and iOS users, offering 186 voices in 30 languages and compatibility with multiple cloud services.

The article also explains the difference between web-based TTS services and desktop software, discusses subscription models, and offers advice for integrating TTS into business workflows. Each software was rigorously tested based on performance, usability, voice quality, and pricing.

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

entries.title: Piotr Dabkowski
entries.snippet:
ElevenLabs, a rapidly growing AI startup co-founded by Polish entrepreneurs Piotr Dabkowski and Mateusz Staniszewski, has developed a state-of-the-art voice cloning technology. This tool allows users to generate lifelike voices from short audio samples and supports speech synthesis in 29 languages, making it highly useful for dubbing and voiceover applications. The company, just two years old, is already valued at $1.1 billion and has secured $80 million in funding from investors like Andreessen Horowitz. Major clients include HarperCollins, TIME, and the Washington Post.

The model stands out for its high quality, low latency, and robustness. Dabkowski notes that the technology is approaching a "quality ceiling," where AI-generated voices are indistinguishable from real human ones, raising ethical and security concerns. To address this, ElevenLabs has built-in safeguards such as credit card verification for access, audio generation tracking, and a speech classifier to detect AI-generated content. The company also participates in the U.S. AI Safety Institute's Consortium. Despite these efforts, some users have bypassed protections, emphasizing the ongoing challenge of preventing misuse in the rapidly evolving landscape of generative AI.

entries.title: Microsoft AI can now clone voices to sound perfectly 'human' in seconds - but it's too dangerous to release to public
entries.snippet:
Microsoft has developed an advanced AI tool called VALL-E 2, a text-to-speech generator that can mimic human voices with near-perfect accuracy using just a few seconds of audio. Trained via zero-shot learning and enhanced with features like Repetition Aware Sampling and Grouped Code Modeling, VALL-E 2 delivers natural, realistic speech, outperforming competing systems in speech robustness and speaker similarity. However, due to the high risk of misuse—such as identity spoofing or political disinformation—Microsoft has chosen not to release the tool publicly and instead categorizes it as a research project. The company warns of potential national security threats, as demonstrated by recent incidents involving AI-generated voices in political robocalls.

Microsoft's decision also reflects broader ethical and societal concerns about artificial intelligence, including job displacement, unauthorized data use, privacy violations, and misinformation. These worries have fueled scrutiny of the company’s AI developments, including its $13 billion partnership with OpenAI. In another case, Microsoft's Recall feature, which captures screen activity, was postponed after facing backlash over privacy issues. Regulators and privacy advocates continue to push for clearer protections and transparency in the use of such advanced AI technologies.

entries.title: Forget Audible - ChatGPT can now read documents and even ebooks out loud to you (and it's surprisingly good)
entries.snippet:
The article from Tom’s Guide highlights a new feature in ChatGPT that allows it to read documents and ebooks aloud, offering a viable alternative to text-to-speech apps like Speechify and audiobook services like Audible. This Read Aloud feature is integrated into the free ChatGPT mobile app for both iPhone and Android users and does not require a ChatGPT Plus subscription. Users can upload a file or paste text into a chat, and ChatGPT reads it back using a natural, human-like voice. 

Compared to paid services, ChatGPT's Read Aloud is praised for being free, seamless, and context-aware, making it especially useful for productivity, writing, and on-the-go listening. Some noted downsides include the manual uploading of documents and occasional interruptions with prompts to continue reading. Regardless, users find it highly effective for most everyday needs and a compelling alternative to pricier or less intuitive solutions.

entries.title: Everlit tool provides auditory experience for readers
entries.snippet: Hearst has introduced a new audio tool powered by Everlit's advanced text-to-speech technology to enhance content accessibility on myplainview.com and its affiliated publications, including the Plainview Herald, Muleshoe Journal, and Canyon News. Most articles will now be available in audio format, read by a lifelike automated voice. This feature aims to benefit readers who prefer auditory experiences or consume news while multitasking or commuting. The audio player is located in a rectangular box just below the article headline and lead image, with a disclaimer noting the narration is by an AI, not a human. While the system produces near-human speech quality, occasional pronunciation errors may occur. Hearst plans ongoing improvements to the pronunciation library to enhance the experience and invites user feedback at eric.young@hearstnp.com.
